bestBHT.bht: The skeptics' misunderstanding of the Lord's patience leads them to perceive it as slackness, but it actually presents an opportunity for repentance and salvation. Peter acknowledges Paul's supernatural wisdom given by God, not acquired through human education, solely to affirm the humility and love in Paul's Epistles. Implications of Christ's delayed return must not be interpreted as a postponement, but exemplify divine long-suffering, allowing ample time for the offer of grace and salvation. Paul's writings effectively reinforce Peter's teachings and possess wisdom that persuades individuals to repent and find salvation.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Those scoffers 'count it (to be the result of) slackness' on the Lord's part.
Our beloved brother Paul—a beautiful instance of love and humility. Peter praises the very Epistles which contain his condemnation.
Supernatural and inspired wisdom 'GIVEN' him, not acquired in human schools of learning.
Albert Barnes: Regard his delay in coming to judge the world, not as an evidence that he never will come, but as a proof of his desire that we should be saved.

Let any man look on his own sins, his pride, and selfishness, and sensuality; let him contemplate the fact that he has sinned through many years, and against many mercies; let him endeavor to estimate the number and magnitude of his offences, and upon God’s patience in bearing with him while these have been committed, and who can overrate the force of such an argument in proof that God is slow to anger, and is willing to save?

Peter evidently did not mean to disparage that wisdom, or to express a doubt that Paul was endowed with wisdom; he meant undoubtedly that, in regard to Paul, the same thing was true which he would have affirmed of himself or of any other man, that whatever wisdom he had was to be traced to a higher than human origin.
John Calvin: He takes it as granted that Christ defers the day of his coming, because he has a regard for our salvation.
Thus, what usually disheartens others through weariness, he wisely turns to a contrary purpose.
It is then probable that Peter referred to Paul in order to shew their consent; for it was very necessary to take away the occasion for such a calumny.
Philip Schaff: And account the long-suffering of our Lord salvation.

The Divine delay is to be interpreted not as 'slackness' or procrastination, but as long-suffering, and the long-suffering is to be interpreted and valued as 'salvation,' as the suspension of judgment with a view to a prolonged offer of grace.
Paul’s counsel was more than his own personal opinion. As the expression of a 'wisdom' which he received, it is the weightier confirmation of Peter’s teaching.
Archibald T. Robertson: Is salvation (σωτηριαν). Predicate accusative after ηγεισθε in apposition with μακροθυμιαν (long-suffering), an opportunity for repentance (cf. 1 Peter 3:20). The Lord here is Christ.

Our beloved brother Paul (ο αγαπητος αδελφος Παυλος). Paul applies the verbal αγαπητος (beloved) to Epaphras (Colossians 1:7), Onesimus (Colossians 4:9; Philemon 1:16), to Tychicus (Colossians 4:7; Ephesians 6:21), and to four brethren in 2 Peter 3:16 (Epainetus Romans 16:5, Ampliatus Romans 16:8, Stachys Romans 16:9, Persis Romans 16:12).

Given to him (δοθεισαν αυτω). First aorist passive participle of διδωμ with dative case. Peter claimed wisdom for himself, but recognises that Paul had the gift also. His language here may have caution in it as well as commendation.
John Gill: Not his longsuffering towards the wicked, and his forbearance with them, for that is not the means of, nor the way to, nor does it issue in, their salvation, but in their sorer punishment and greater damnation.
He waits, he stays, that none of them might perish, but that they might be all brought to faith and repentance, and so be saved.

[Paul] was indeed a wise master builder, and whatever he wrote was 'according to wisdom'; not fleshly wisdom, the wisdom of this world, nor with enticing words of men's wisdom, but according to the divine wisdom, under the influence of the spirit of wisdom and revelation.
John Wesley: And account the longsuffering of the Lord salvation — Not only designed to lead men to repentance, but actually conducing thereto: a precious means of saving many more souls.
As our beloved brother Paul also hath written to you — This refers not only to the single sentence preceding, but to all that went before.
St. Paul had written to the same effect concerning the end of the world, in several parts of his epistles, and particularly in his Epistle to the Hebrews. Romans 2:4.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse emphasizes the misguided perception of scoffers who interpret the long-suffering of the Lord as an indication of His slackness rather than recognizing it as an opportunity for repentance and salvation. This passage coincides with Peter's acknowledgment of Paul's supernatural wisdom, which was not acquired through human learning, but given to him by God Himself. Peter commends Paul's Epistles, highlighting the humility and love exhibited by his words, which serves to confirm and support Peter's own teachings. The delay in Christ's return should not be misconstrued as procrastination, but rather as an act of divine long-suffering, providing an extended period for the offer of grace and salvation. Paul's writings further reinforce Peter's teachings, as they carry the weight of divine wisdom and serve as a means to lead people to repentance and ultimately, salvation.

The skeptics' misunderstanding of the Lord's patience leads them to perceive it as slackness, but it actually presents an opportunity for repentance and salvation. Peter acknowledges Paul's supernatural wisdom given by God, not acquired through human education, solely to affirm the humility and love in Paul's Epistles. Implications of Christ's delayed return must not be interpreted as a postponement, but exemplify divine long-suffering, allowing ample time for the offer of grace and salvation. Paul's writings effectively reinforce Peter's teachings and possess wisdom that persuades individuals to repent and find salvation.

Misguided scoffers view the Lord's patience as slackness, failing to recognize it as an opportunity for repentance and salvation. Peter praises Paul's supernatural wisdom, not acquired through human learning but given by God Himself. Paul's Epistles resonate with humility and love, serving to confirm and support Peter's teachings. The delay in Christ's return should not be seen as procrastination, but as divine long-suffering, offering extended grace and salvation. Paul's writings carry the weight of divine wisdom, leading people to repentance and ultimate salvation.

The scoffers mistakenly interpret the Lord's patience as slackness, unaware that it provides an opportunity for repentance and salvation. Peter commends Paul's supernatural wisdom, emphasizing that it was given, not acquired through human schools of learning. The delay in Christ's return is not a sign of procrastination but a manifestation of divine long-suffering, allowing for an extended offer of grace. Paul's writings, reflecting divine wisdom, reinforce Peter's teachings and guide individuals towards repentance and the path of salvation.

The skeptics' misconception of the Lord's patience results in them seeing it as slackness, instead of recognizing it as a chance for repentance and salvation. Peter praises Paul's supernatural wisdom, bestowed upon him by God rather than obtained through human education. Paul's Epistles, which exhibit humility and love, serve as a validation and support of Peter's teachings. The delay in Christ's return should not be interpreted as procrastination, but rather as an act of divine long-suffering, providing more time for the offer of grace and salvation.
